question.question-text: Why are the students discussing this material?

answer-list.answer-text: They are preparing to attend a lecture.
They are going over material presented by a professor.
They are reviewing material on an exam.
They are working on a report.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, one of the students says the professor sure spent a lot of time discussing those huge earthquakes near the Mississippi. From this, it can be determined that the students are going over material presented by a professor. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Where was the center of the earthquakes discussed by the students?

answer-list.answer-text: Near the Missouri River in the state of Mississippi
In the Mississippi river valley in the state of Mississippi

answer-text.exp: In the Mississippi river valley in the state of Missouri

answer-list.answer-text: Near the Missouri River in the state of Mississippi

question.explain-text: In the discussion, one of the students says the quakes were centered in the state of Missouri and not Mississippi, but they were in the Mississippi river valley in Missouri. From this, it can be determined that the center of the earthquakes discussed by the students was in the Mississippi river valley in the state of Missouri. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Based on the information in the discussion, indicate whether the statements below are true about the Mississippi earthquakes.

answer-list.answer-text: They took place in the eighteenth century.
They took place over a three-month period.
They were extremely strong.
They were felt only along the Mississippi River.

explain-list.explain-text: The students mention the earthquakes and state that they were in the early 1800s, in the winter of 1811 to 1812 and that that would be the early part of the nineteenth century. This means that it is NOT true that they took place in the eighteenth century. You should therefore click in the NO column.

One of the students states that there were big earthquakes in December, in January, and again in February. This means that they took place over a three-month period. You should therefore click in the YES column.

One of the students states that these were supposedly the most powerful earthquakes ever recorded in North America and that they were so strong that they could be felt all the way up the East Coast. This means that they were extremely strong. You should therefore click in the YES column.

One of the students says the professor said that they could be felt over an area of more than a million square miles. This means that it is NOT true that they were felt only along the Mississippi River. You should therefore click in the NO column.

question.question-text: According to the students, what topographical changes occurred as a result of the Mississippi earthquakes?

answer-list.answer-text: Rivers disappeared.
Land sank.
Volcanic craters formed.
New lakes formed.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, the second man states that over 30,000 square miles of land sank and that lakes were formed. This means that land sank and new lakes formed. The second and last answers are therefore the best answers to this question.

question.question-text: What can be concluded from the discussion about 5 percent of the world's earthquakes?

answer-list.answer-text: They occur in Mississippi.
They are not explained by the theory of plate tectonics.
They develop in the middle of the North American plate.
They result from movement along the borders of tectonic plates.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, one of the students states that according to the theory of plate tectonics, earthquakes can occur when the large plates that make up the crust of the Earth move and push up against each other, and another states that 5 percent of the earthquakes occur in the middle of large plates. It can be concluded from this that about 5 percent of the world's earthquakes are not explained by the theory of plate tectonics. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Why did the professor most likely discuss these earthquakes and plate tectonics in the same lecture?

answer-list.answer-text: The earthquakes support the theory of plate tectonics.
The earthquakes occurred where two huge plates crashed together.
The earthquakes led to the theory of plate tectonics.
The earthquakes fail to support the theory of plate tectonics.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, one of the students states that according to the theory of plate tectonics, earthquakes can occur when the large plates that make up the crust of the Earth move and push up against each other, and another student states that the Mississippi earthquakes are intraplate earthquakes and they're part of the 5 percent of earthquakes that occur in the middle of plates and not part of the 95 percent of earthquakes that occur along the edges of plates. From this, it can be determined that the professor discussed these earthquakes and plate tectonics in the same lecture because the earthquakes fail to support the theory of plate tectonics. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.
